questions.question: A 65-year-old patient presents with constipation, abdominal pain, nausea, vomiting, confusion, and bone pain. Laboratory tests reveal elevated calcium levels. Considering the role of the calcium-sensing receptor (CaSR) in calcium homeostasis, which of the following is regulated by CaSR?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: A) PTH Explanation: The parathyroid glands, located behind the thyroid, consist of four small glands that produce parathyroid hormone (PTH) , an 84-amino acid peptide. The calcium-sensing receptor (CaSR), a G-protein-coupled receptor (GPCR) regulates PTH secretion, which responds to changes in serum calcium levels. Functions of PTH: In response to low serum calcium: Increases calcium reabsorption and promotes phosphate excretion (phosphaturia) in renal tubules. Enhances osteoclastic activity, facilitating bone resorption, while also supporting bone formation. Stimulates the activation of vitamin D3, converting 25-hydroxyvitamin D to its active form, 1,25-dihydroxyvitamin D. Significance of PTH: Hypoparathyroidism: PTH decreases, resulting in decreased calcium and increased phosphate levels in the blood (reduced phosphaturia). Hyperparathyroidism: PTH increases, leading to increased bone turnover or remodelling (SAP or serum alkaline phosphatase is the marker for bone turnover). Turnover or Remodelling" data-author="NA" data-hash="8555" data-license="NA" data-source="NA" data-tags="April2025" height="306" src="https://image.prepladder.com/notes/MWNo6yWas90bCtCZLm161744291728.png" width="309" /> FGF-23 (Fibroblast growth factor 23) (Option B) is a phosphaturic hormone that suppresses parathyroid hormone (PTH). It regulates calcium and phosphate metabolism by reducing phosphate levels and increasing calcium levels in the blood, which can lead to nephrolithiasis. Vitamin D3 (Option C) promotes calcium absorption, bone mineralisation and tissue differentiation. Deficiency of this vitamin leads to hypocalcemia, rickets, and osteomalacia , while its excess can result in hypercalcemia. Calcitonin (Option D) is a peptide hormone secreted by the parafollicular C cells of the thyroid gland. It is a tumour marker in medullary thyroid carcinoma and can be used therapeutically for conditions such as osteoporosis and Paget’s disease of bone.

questions.question: A 60-year-old female presents with complaints of abdominal pain, constipation, and recent episodes of confusion and depression. Laboratory tests reveal elevated serum calcium and alkaline phosphatase (SAP) levels and decreased phosphate levels. Which of the following clinical features is not typically associated with this condition?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: C) Tetany Explanation: The scenario of constipation, abdominal pain, elevated calcium levels, increased bone turnover (indicated by elevated alkaline phosphatase), and decreased phosphate levels suggests Primary Hyperparathyroidism , where tetany is not observed; instead, it is typically seen in hypoparathyroidism. Primary Hyperparathyroidism: Cause: Autonomous secretion of PTH (most commonly due to parathyroid adenoma) Clinical features: Stones, bone, groans and psychiatric moans It is more common in the 3rd-5th decade of life. Renal features: Recurrent Nephrolithiasis (Stones), nephrocalcinosis (calcium deposition in the kidney), urinary tract obstruction, infection or renal failure. Skeletal system: Osteitis fibrosa cystica (Bones) Increased bone resorption by osteoclasts leads to fibrous replacement in the lacunae, leading to bone pain and tenderness. Gastrointestinal: Abdominal pain (groans) , constipation , nausea, vomiting. Psychiatric: Psychosis, depression, confusion . (Psychiatric moans) Cardiovascular system: Systolic arrest can occur in severe cases (calcium>15mg%). It is associated with MEN1 or MEN 2/2A syndrome. Tetany (Option C) is characterized by muscle spasms resulting from increased excitability of peripheral nerves due to serum calcium levels falling below 7 mg/dL, as seen in hypoparathyroidism.

questions.question: A 39-year-old woman presents with persistent constipation, abdominal pain, and intermittent lower back pain. She has a history of recurrent kidney stones and reports fatigue. Lab tests reveal elevated calcium and decreased phosphate levels. She has been advised to undergo a sestamibi Tc-99 scan. Which of the following is not an indication for surgery in this condition?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: C) Age >50 years Explanation: The given scenario indicates Primary Hyperparathyroidism , where the treatment of choice is surgical excision of the tumor . The indications for surgery include nephrolithiasis, renal impairment, osteoporosis, and age under 50 years. Lab Investigations: Serum calcium levels: Increased Serum phosphate levels: Decreased Serum alkaline phosphatase (SAP) levels: Increased Serum PTH (parathyroid hormone) assay: Elevated PTH Radiological features: Features Image Subperiosteal erosions and terminal resorption in the phalanges (usually starts in the middle phalanx of the index finger's radial side) along with bone demineralisation. The "salt and pepper" appearance, or pepper pot skull (lytic lesions in the skull). Brown tumour or osteitis fibrosa cystica: Cystic lesions in bone from excessive osteoclastic resorption appear as low-density, multiloculated cysts that can lead to bone expansion, accompanied by bleeding and granulation tissue. Sestamibi scan (Tc-99): Localize the tumour . Management Surgical excision of parathyroid adenoma (Treatment of choice) Indications for surgery: Age <50 years (Option C) Nephrolithiasis confirmed by imaging (Option A) Elevated serum calcium level (documented) Osteoporosis confirmed by DEXA scan (T-score < -2.5 S.D.) (Option D) Renal impairment (creatinine clearance <60 ml/min) (Option B) Elevated urinary calcium levels (24 hours) Vertebral fracture confirmed by imaging Asymptomatic cases: Conservative treatment Annual monitoring of calcium and renal profile Periodic monitoring of bone density

questions.question: A 45-year-old woman presents to the emergency department with muscle cramps, tingling in her fingers, and a tight sensation around her mouth. She has a history of thyroid surgery for papillary carcinoma. Examination revealed increased neuromuscular excitability. Lab results show low PTH, low calcium, and elevated phosphate levels. Which syndrome is most likely associated with this presentation?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: D) DiGeorge syndrome Explanation: The condition described, characterized by neuromuscular excitability, low calcium, low PTH, and elevated phosphate levels, is diagnosed as Hypoparathyroidism , which can be associated with DiGeorge syndrome . Causes and conditions associated with Hypoparathyroidism: Post-operative patients (total thyroidectomy): Removal of parathyroid glands during total thyroidectomy (papillary thyroid cancer) Reimplantation of the parathyroid gland is performed in the brachioradialis (preferred) or sternocleidomastoid muscles to prevent hypoparathyroidism. Autoimmune polyendocrine syndrome (Type 1): Also known as Autoimmune poly-endocrinopathy-candidiasis-ectodermal dystrophy (APECED) Autosomal recessive Chromosome 21 AIRE gene defect (loss of function mutation). DiGeorge Syndrome (Option D) Failure of development of the 3rd and 4th pharyngeal pouches Features - CATTCH-22 Deletion of chromosome 22q11 C ongenital heart disease A bnormal facial features - Low set ears and hypertelorism T hymus gland abnormalities or absence T racheo-esopahgeal fistulas C left platelet/lip H ypoparathyroidism and H ypocalcemia It is rarely caused by hemochromatosis or Wilson’s disease. Cushing’s syndrome (Option A) is characterised by excess cortisol, which leads to symptoms such as weight gain (moon facies), tiredness, muscle weakness, hypertension, mood swings, hirsutism, osteoporosis, and elevated blood sugar. It is not associated with hypocalcemia, low PTH, or neuromuscular excitability. McCune-Albright Syndrome (Option B) is a genetic disorder caused by an active mutation in a G protein (mosaic pattern). It involves bone abnormalities (fibrous dysplasia), skin pigmentation, and endocrine issues (e.g., precocious puberty). It does not typically affect the parathyroid glands or cause hypocalcemia. Turner syndrome (Option C) is a genetic disorder affecting females, characterised by a 45XO karyotype. It presents with short stature, a fish-like mouth, a high-arched palate, a webbed neck, a broad chest, and underdeveloped ovaries, leading to primary amenorrhea and infertility . It is not associated with parathyroid dysfunction or abnormal calcium and phosphate levels.

questions.question: A 45-year-old woman undergoes total thyroidectomy for a large goiter. Two days post-surgery, investigations reveal low serum calcium and low parathyroid hormone (PTH) levels. During clinical examination, the following observation is made. What is this sign known as ?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: B) Chvostek sign Explanation: Chvostek's sign is a clinical sign of hypocalcemia, where tapping over the facial nerve (at the parotid gland) causes twitching of the facial muscles. This occurs due to the increased neuromuscular excitability caused by l ow calcium levels , commonly seen in hypoparathyroidism. Hypoparathyroidism Clinical symptoms Paresthesia and tingling sensation of fingers and lips Seizures Bronchospasm Laryngospasm Clinical signs Q-T prolongation Trousseau sign It is elicited by inflating a blood pressure cuff over the upper arm to 20 mm Hg above the patient’s systolic blood pressure for three minutes. This temporarily occludes the brachial artery, resulting in the development of carpopedal spasm, often referred to as "Obstetrician's hand." Chvostek sign is observed when gentle tapping on the anterior border of the parotid gland causes twitching of the muscles around the lips.

questions.question: A 52-year-old man diagnosed with hypoparathyroidism six months ago after neck surgery presents with tingling in his hands and feet, muscle cramps, and fatigue. His lab results indicate low serum calcium, elevated phosphate, and severely low parathyroid hormone (PTH) levels. What is the most appropriate treatment for his condition?

options.D: Start oral calcium and Vitamin D supplement

questions.explanation: Correct Answer: C) Administration of Teriparatide Explanation: The treatment of choice for surgically induced hypoparathyroidism is the administration of recombinant PTH , specifically PTH-teriparatide. Hypoparathyroidism Investigations Serum calcium : ↓ Serum parathyroid hormone : ↓↓↓ Serum albumin : Normal ECG : QT prolongation Treatment For hypocalcemia crisis: Calcium gluconate 10% IV injection is given (Option A) Teriparatide: DOC for surgically induced hypoparathyroidism (Option C) Calcium and vitamin D supplements (Option D) Administration of Alendronate (Option B) is the DOC for osteoporosis or conditions with high bone turnover. In hypoparathyroidism, low calcium levels result from low parathyroid hormone, not increased bone resorption. Using bisphosphonates would worsen hypocalcemia by inhibiting bone resorption, making this an inappropriate treatment. Reference: Harrison’s principle of internal medicine, 21st edition, Page 3187

questions.question: A 65-year-old woman with primary hyperparathyroidism presents with nausea, vomiting, confusion, and dehydration. She shows signs of hypovolemia and altered mental status. Labs reveal high serum calcium, low phosphate, and elevated PTH. What is the first line of treatment?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: B) Aggressive hydration with normal saline Explanation: The first line of treatment in hypercalcemic crises is aggressive hydration with normal saline. Hypercalcemic crisis: Aetiology: Hypercalcemia of malignancy Paraneoplastic syndromes in Squamous cell carcinoma of lungs Breast carcinoma Parathyroid adenoma Sarcoidosis Vitamin D toxicity Milk alkali syndrome Jansen disease: Autosomal dominant defect in PTHR-1 leading to receptor gain mutation (hyperactive receptor) Lithium toxicity: Causes diabetes insipidus and activation of parathyroid glands. Familial hypocalciuric hypercalcemia: Autosomal dominant defect in CaSR receptor in parathyroid and kidneys, which leads to excess PTH secretion Investigations: Serum electrolytes: ↑ calcium and ↓ phosphate. ↑ Serum alkaline phosphatase. ↑↑↑ Serum PTH in cases of parathyroid adenoma Treatment: Aggressive hydration with normal saline: First-line management to correct dehydration and promote renal calcium excretion. Forced diuresis with loop diuretics: Can be used after adequate hydration to enhance calcium excretion in the urine. Intravenous Zoledronate : Drug of choice for lowering calcium. It begins to act within 1-2 days and lasts up to 3 weeks. Calcitonin: Promotes calcium deposition in bones but may develop tachyphylaxis (reduced response over time). Denosumab: Inhibits osteoclast differentiation by binding to RANK ligand, reducing bone resorption. Peritoneal dialysis: Indicated in renal failure, it can rapidly reverse life-threatening hypercalcemia. Reference: Harrison’s principle of internal medicine, 21st edition, Page 3182-3183

questions.question: A 45-year-old adult patient presents with symptoms of chronic hypocalcemia. Which of the following features is associated with this condition?

options.B: Tissue deposition of calcium due to hyperphosphatemia

questions.explanation: Correct Answer: D) All of the above Explanation: Chronic Hypocalcemia Pathology In chronic hypocalcemia, often associated with conditions like chronic kidney disease, hyperphosphatemia can lead to ectopic calcifications in tissues. (Option B) Basal ganglia calcification can occur. Clinical features Extrapyramidal symptoms like dystonia (Option A) , oculogyric crisis and Hemiballismus Ocular cataract Abnormal dentition Autoimmune polyglandular syndrome Cutaneous candidiasis (Option C) Salt wasting Postural hypotension Investigation Serum calcium ↓ Serum phosphate ↑ Serum PTH ↓↓ Treatment Calcium and Vitamin D supplements Teriparatide (if due to iatrogenic etiology)

questions.question: An 8-year-old boy presents with characteristic skeletal and developmental defects, such as short stature and shortened 4th and 5th metacarpals. Laboratory findings show elevated PTH levels, hypocalcemia, and hyperphosphatemia. Genetic testing reveals a deficiency in the Gs α subunit. Based on these findings, what is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: B) Pseudohypoparathyroidism type 1a (PHP1A) Explanation: Hypoparathyroidism Pseudohypoparathyroidism Pseudopseudohypoparathyroidism Cause Injury to parathyroids Autoimmune DiGeorge’s syndrome Autosomal dominant maternally transmitted mutation in GNAS1 gene Autosomal dominant paternally transmitted mutation in GNAS1 gene Pathology Reduced secretion of hypoparathyroidism Inactivation of adenylate cyclase when PTH binds to its receptor. PHP Type 1A (PHP1A): Deficiency in the Gs alpha subunit. PHP Type 1B (PHP1B): Gs alpha subunit is present, but the tissue response to PTH is impaired. PHP Type 2 (PHP2): Gs alpha subunit is present, and there is no significant resistance to PTH. Inactivation of adenylate cyclase when PTH binds to its receptor only in the bones. Gs alpha subunit is deficient. Features Tetany Hypocalcemia Chvostek sign Trousseau sign Hyperphosphatemia Albright hereditary osteodystrophy (shortened 4th and 5th digit) Short stature Round face Subcutaneous calcifications Developmental delay Albright hereditary osteodystrophy (shortened 4th and 5th digit) Renal response to PTH present Serum findings PTH ↓↓ Calcium ↓ Phosphate ↑ PTH ↑ Calcium ↓ Phosphate ↑ PTH - normal Calcium - normal Phosphate - normal Hereditary Syndrome" data-author="Trejo, Camila & Roman-Gonzalez, Alejandro & Ruiz, Sebastian & Tobón, Catalina & Castaño, Pablo & Arango, Clara & Prieto, Carolina." data-hash="9358" data-license="CC BY 3.0" data-source="h ttps://www.researchgate.net/figure/Phenotypic-traits-of-Albrights-hereditary-osteodystophy-case-4-A-shortening- of-the_fig2_329997472" data-tags="April2025" height="342" src="https://image.prepladder.com/notes/syqP7Jo45bwBm91LeRC21744369856.png" width="400" /> Reference: Harrison’s principle of internal medicine, 21st edition, Page 3188

questions.question: A 65-year-old woman with a history of chronic kidney disease secondary to hypertension presents with symptoms of nausea, vomiting, and confusion. On Investigating her Lab values are Serum calcium: 12.0 mg/dL (normal range: 8.5-10.5 mg/dL) Serum phosphate: 4.9 mg/dL (normal range: 2.5-4.5 mg/dL) Serum PTH: 200 pg/mL (normal range: 10-65 pg/mL) Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis of this patient?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: D) Tertiary Hyperparathyroidism Explanation: Tertiary hyperparathyroidism occurs due to excessive secretion of parathyroid hormone (PTH) following prolonged secondary hyperparathyroidism, commonly seen in patients with chronic kidney disease (CKD). Cinacalcet (calcimimetic agent) is used to manage this condition and reduce PTH production. Primary Hyperparathyroidism (Option A ruled out) Secondary Hyperparathyroidism (Option B ruled out) Tertiary Hyperparathyroidism (Option D) Pseudohypoparathyroidism (Option C ruled out) Cause Adenoma (Common) Hyperplasia Carcinoma CKD Prolonged secondary hyperparathyroidism in CKD Due to gene mutation in the GNAS1 gene. questions.question: A 35-year-old man presents with recurrent kidney stones, abdominal pain, and peptic ulcers. His blood pressure is elevated, and he has a family history of thyroid carcinoma. Laboratory tests reveal high serum calcium and parathyroid hormone levels. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: D) MEN Type 2 Explanation: Multiple Endocrine Neoplasia (MEN) Type 2: It includes parathyroid adenoma, pheochromocytoma and medullary cell carcinoma of the thyroid . Recurrent kidney stones are due to Hypercalcemia caused by Primary hyperparathyroidism, and its elevated PTH causes increased gastric secretion, contributing to abdominal pain and peptic ulcers. Pheochromocytoma causes high blood pressure due to excessive secretion of catecholamines (epinephrine and norepinephrine) from the adrenal medulla. MEN is a group of genetic syndromes ( Autosomal Dominant ) characterized by the development of tumors in multiple endocrine glands. Diagnostic criteria for MEN is Clinical features of 2 or more associated tumors Notable Family history Confirmation by genetic analysis. Types of Multiple Endocrine Neoplasia MEN Type I MEN Type II MEN Type III MEN Type IV Cause Defect of chromosome 11q13 causing MEN 1 gene mutation Also called Wermer’s syndrome Defect of chr.10 leading to mutation of RET gene Also called Sipple’s syndrome Also called MEN II B , it is a variant of Type 2 MEN Defect of chr.12 causing CDKN1B gene Tumors Included Parathyroid adenoma (most common) It presents with primary hyperparathyroidism ( ↑ PTH and ↑ Ca) All the 4 glands can be included. Rx: Total/subtotal parathyroid resection Parathyroid adenoma ( most common, and calcium can be normal) Medullary carcinoma thyroid ( most common) Parathyroid adenoma ( Presents as hypercalcemia) Pancreatic adenoma Presents as Gastrinoma or Zollinger-Ellison syndrome This leads to peptic ulcer disease in the duodenum, which is the leading cause of death in this type. Pheochromocytoma . Pheochromocytoma (Most important criterion for both MEN 2 and MEN 3): Presents with elevated blood pressure. Pituitary adenoma: Prolactinoma Pituitary adenoma: Prolactinoma, causing amenorrhea and Infertility Medullary thyroid carcinoma Calcitonin is the tumor marker present Cold nodules are seen on the thyroid scan Metastasis can be traced with PET scan Visible neck mass, causing dysphagia Rx - Prophylactic thyroidectomy Reproductive tract tumors Testicular tumors Neuroendocrine tumor (Cervix) Associated conditions Angio I broma Collagenoma Adrenocortical tumor Carcinoid tumors/Argenta I noma Pheochromocytoma (only in 1%) Congenital aganglionosis, Hirschsprung disease Marfanoid habitus Medullated corneal nerve I bers Mucosal neuromas Megacolon and Multiple diverticulae Occasionally with Renal tumor Adrenal tumor Reference: Harrison’s principle of internal medicine, 21st edition, Page 2983 - 2990 Davidson’s Principles and Practice of Medicine, 24th Edition, Page 868, 869

questions.question: A 50-year-old man presents with notable fatigue, frequent urination, and increased thirst. He has a family history of autoimmune disorders. Laboratory tests reveal elevated blood glucose levels and positive autoantibodies. Autoimmune Polyendocrine Syndrome(APS) is suspected. Which of the following statements regarding the diagnosis is not true?

options.A: Type 1 is a mutation of the AIRE gene
options.B: Type 2 APS can be associated with Celiac sprue
options.C: Type 1 APS can be associated with mucocutaneous candida.
options.D: Hypoparathyroidism is a part of Type 1 APS

questions.explanation: Correct Answer: D) Hypoparathyroidism is a part of Type 1 APS Explanation: Hypoparathyroidism is a part of APS type 2 , which is a gene defect in the HLA complex and is known to be more common than type 1. APS is a group of disorders characterized by the simultaneous occurrence of multiple autoimmune conditions affecting the endocrine system, which are also associated with non-endocrine conditions. Autoimmune Polyendocrine Syndrome Type 1 Type 2 Onset is early Onset is late Rare condition Comparatively more common No sex differentiation Female > Male Chr.21, the AIRE gene is affected Due to gene defects in the HLA complex Endocrine conditions Addison’s disease Hypoparathyroidism Hypogonadism Graves’ disease or autoimmune thyroiditis Type 1 Diabetes mellitus Endocrine conditions: Similar to Type 1, but Hypoparathyroidism is not a part. Non-endocrine associations Mucocutaneous candidiasis Chronic active hepatitis Asplenism Ectodermal dysplasia Malabsorption syndromes Non-endocrine associations Celiac disease Dermatitis herpetiformis Myasthenia gravis Parkinson’s disease Idiopathic thrombocytopenia Common non-endocrine associations of APS Pernicious anemia Vitiligo IgA deficiency Alopecia Reference: Harrison’s principle of internal medicine, 21st edition, Page 2992, 2993

questions.question: A 28-year-old woman presents with complaints of irregular menstrual cycles and infertility & reports increased headaches and visual changes over the past few months. An MRI reveals a large pituitary tumor. Family history is significant for several relatives with breast and thyroid cancers. Which syndrome is most likely associated with her condition?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: C) Cowden Syndrome Explanation: The most likely diagnosis is Cowden Syndrome, characterized by a family history of breast and thyroid cancers and pituitary tumors. The patient's symptoms of irregular menstrual cycles, infertility, and the pituitary tumor on MRI are consistent with this syndrome. Cowden Syndrome: Caused by a PTEN gene mutation on chromosome 10 q23.31. Characterized by multiple hamartomas affecting the skin, mucous membranes, and organs, including the thyroid, and is associated with an increased risk of thyroid, breast, and pituitary tumors. Endocrine manifestations, such as prolactin-secreting pituitary adenomas, can lead to irregular menstrual cycles and infertility, necessitating regular monitoring for potential pituitary involvement. McCune-Albright Syndrome (MAS) (Option A) is caused by a postzygotic mutation in the GNAS1 gene and is characterized by a triad of: Polyostotic fibrous dysplasia Café-au-lait skin pigmentation Precocious puberty Endocrine abnormalities like hyperthyroidism and Cushing's syndrome can also occur due to adrenal tumors. Pituitary tumors, particularly somatotroph tumors leading to acromegaly, may develop. Von Hippel-Lindau (VHL) Disease (Option B) is an autosomal dominant disorder caused by a mutation in the VHL gene on chromosome 3. It is characterized by: Hemangioblastomas of the retina and CNS Cysts in multiple organs Renal cell carcinoma Pheochromocytomas Pancreatic islet cell tumors While pituitary tumors are less common, they may occur as part of broader endocrine dysfunction. Carney complex (CNC) (Option D) is caused by a mutation in the PRKAR1A gene on chromosome 17q . It is characterized by: Myxomas, particularly cardiac Spotty skin pigmentation Endocrine tumors, including adrenal tumors causing Cushing's syndrome About 10% of CNC patients may develop growth hormone-secreting pituitary adenomas, leading to acromegaly, making regular screening for pituitary tumors essential. Reference: Harrison’s Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st Edition, Page 2990, 2991, 2992
